Name: Rosina's Chambers
Description: The cavern is crowded. In the center is a bathtub full of ice, in which sits a woman in an obvious state of illness. Several Antheans attend her, one with deft, clear fingers. Then there are a number of other people attending, who mostly talk among themselves, but sometimes turn to watch Rosina.

DefaultEvent.Name: A settled audience
DefaultEvent.Description:
Rosina braces herself in the ice bath and prepares for the Song. You cannot replicate exactly how it sounds in the air-water of Dahut, but its contradictions come through clear enough. It is hard to take either joy or sorrow too seriously, if you believe the Song. 

"I feel positively indifferent," Rosina says afterwards. It is a compliment.

ChildBranches.Name: Present a Drownie Counterpoint to Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: The light and gloom might counteract one another. Would this hasten Rosina's animescence, or slow it?

DefaultEvent.Name: Unmovingly alien
DefaultEvent.Description: The song and all it celebrates is alien to Rosina: she cannot understand it well enough to be moved by it. The confusion and apathy are a tonic to her animescence. Her skin cools and she looks significantly healthier than she did before.

ChildBranches.Name: Perform a Drownie Hymn for Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: There might be a healing effect to its harmonies.

DefaultEvent.Name: In the upper arm, beneath the skin
DefaultEvent.Description: Rosina makes no sound as you puncture her arm. In a moment she knows that you have tricked her: there is some horrible recollection in the Needle, and she weeps as she remembers it. Her cheeks are flushed with the effects of animescence, and the tears evaporate away again almost at once.

ChildBranches.Name: Offer Rosina a Needle of Fortas
ChildBranches.Description: If you tell her it is a sort of medicine, she might permit it.

DefaultEvent.Name: The staircase
DefaultEvent.Description: The way is steep, up cut stone stairs. Sometimes it becomes a ladder rather than a staircase at all. After the first few flights, you can no longer hear the murmur of conversation in the sickroom.

ChildBranches.Name: Return to the rest of Anthe
ChildBranches.Description: Leave the sick-chambers.

DefaultEvent.Name: Baked from within
DefaultEvent.Description:
Rosina is dying of animescence, the disease of the Elder Continent. Any passion speeds the disease. She must, therefore, lie very still in an ice bath and think of things that do not interest her. Going sharp in the spleen protects her against the passion of anger, but other passions are still a danger.

For a long time she looked for a cure to the disease. Tradition ascribes healing features to certain poems, ointments, and postures of the body. But these only delay the gradual combustion.

ChildBranches.Name: Meet Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: She has seen you come in.

DefaultEvent.Name: She tells you her story
DefaultEvent.Description: For a long time, she looked for cures of the body. "I was certain the inhabitants of the Elder Continent would be able to correct what is wrong," she says. "But if they know how, they refuse to say. Now... I merely keep back the disease as long as I can, and seek cures of the sentiment instead. If I keep very calm, my symptoms subside. If you find anything in your travels – works of philosophy or guidance – that might help me compose myself, please bring them to me."

ChildBranches.Name: Learn more of Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: Speak to her of her choices and what she requires.

DefaultEvent.Name: What begins as a traveler's tale...
DefaultEvent.Description: You present your story as though it were simply a documentary account, a bit ordinary, nothing to threaten the balance of her mind. It is only slowly that you introduce the romance between two of the characters, the understated devotion, the inevitable betrayal. Rosina listens with her eyes closed, never startled into alarm, but the ice around her begins to melt. You can feel the heat from here.

ChildBranches.Name: Tell Rosina a story from Low Barnet
ChildBranches.Description: It will likely speed up the progress of her illness.

ChildBranches.Name: Witness Rosina's Death
ChildBranches.Description: She is very near destruction now. You have done enough.

ChildBranches.Name: Witness Rosina's Recovery
ChildBranches.Description: She has been looking better and better.

DefaultEvent.Name: Once more up the narrow staircase
DefaultEvent.Description: The walls are slick with condensed steam. There is a sheen of ice on the steps.

ChildBranches.Name: Return to the rest of Anthe
ChildBranches.Description: You have nothing more to do here.

DefaultEvent.Name: Once more up the narrow staircase
DefaultEvent.Description: The walls are slick with condensed steam. There is a sheen of ice on the steps.

ChildBranches.Name: Depart without saying anything to her
ChildBranches.Description: It is none of your concern whether she lives or dies.

DefaultEvent.Name: Curative tedium
DefaultEvent.Description:
You explain the masks. You establish the etiquette associated with each one. You rely upon the most technical of anthropological vocabulary. You allow yourself some reflections upon theories of esquivalience as they pertain to performative duties in highly dissimulative societies...

Rosina's nurse touches your elbow. "First sound sleep she's had in weeks," she whispers, with a nod at the resting patient. "It'll do wonders for her. Specially if she can avoid dreaming."

ChildBranches.Name: Provide a dry lecture on the social stratification of Visage
ChildBranches.Description: Obscure pedantry might be just the thing for Rosina. You have the tongue to tell it.

DefaultEvent.Name: A settled audience
DefaultEvent.Description:
Rosina braces herself in the ice bath and prepares for the Song. You cannot replicate exactly how it sounds in the air-water of Dahut, but its contradictions come through clear enough. It is hard to take either joy or sorrow too seriously, if you believe the Song.

You sing for a long time. Rosina looks ever more meditative and tranquil. One of the onlookers takes off his robe and leaves the room before you finally finish.

ChildBranches.Name: Sing the Drownie Counterpoint at extra length and subtlety
ChildBranches.Description: The light and gloom might counteract one another, and you have the singing voice to perform it with more than typical control.

DefaultEvent.Description: She shakes her head. "Look at me. Immersed; confined. If I were to pursue a cause, or expose myself to... old, fierce relationships, I would irreparably hasten my condition. No. In my present state, I cannot. Perhaps if I were recovered. Or perhaps Mariam can suggest a replacement. I would understand."

ChildBranches.Name: Ask Rosina to rejoin the Seven Against Nidah
ChildBranches.Description: She was their Healer.

DefaultEvent.Name: A love letter consumed, consuming
DefaultEvent.Description:
Did you fail to mention the nature of the letter? Rosina is reads her lover's words. At the first sentence, the page singes at her touch. Another line and the ice in her tub steams. 

A quick-witted nurse leaps to prevent disaster. "Get out," she growls, having sequestered the letter in her apron. "Tell Lorenzo his love will be her death." Rosina is silent, but her eyes burn.

ChildBranches.Name: Present a love letter to Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: A wisp of steam curls from her neck at the mention of the author's name. This must be done delicately.

DefaultEvent.Name: Resisted
DefaultEvent.Description:
"Enough!" She holds up a hand almost at the first note. "I recognise the tune. Who let you in here? Are you an agent of the Continent? Get out." If her spleen weren't a lump of crystal, she would be much angrier.

Her attendants bundle you ignominiously back up the staircase. Better luck next time, perhaps.

ChildBranches.Name: Perform a Drownie Love-song for Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: She won't have heard this one before. Of course, if she's strong enough, she will resist.

DefaultEvent.Name: Out!
DefaultEvent.Description:
Rosina sits up at the first sentence. "Who let you in here? Are you an agent of the Nidaheen? You must leave." If her spleen weren't a lump of crystal, she would be much angrier.

Her attendants bundle you ignominiously back up the staircase. Better luck next time, perhaps.

ChildBranches.Name: Read some Romantic Literature to Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: It would be very bad for her, of course. She will resist if she is strong enough.

DefaultEvent.Name: Out!
DefaultEvent.Description:
Rosina sits up at the first sentence. "Who let you in here? Are you an agent of the Nidaheen? You must leave." If her spleen weren't a lump of crystal, she would be much angrier.

Her attendants bundle you ignominiously back up the staircase. Better luck next time, perhaps.

ChildBranches.Name: Read Approved Romantic Literature to Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: It would be very bad for her, of course. She will resist if she is strong enough.

DefaultEvent.Name: Out!
DefaultEvent.Description:
Rosina sits up at the first sentence. "Who let you in here? Are you an agent of the Nidaheen? You must leave." If her spleen weren't a lump of crystal, she would be much angrier.

Her attendants bundle you ignominiously back up the staircase. Better luck next time, perhaps.

ChildBranches.Name: Read Anthean Romance to Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: She will resist if she is strong enough, but the revised volume is very seductive. She may not have the will.

DefaultEvent.Name: Carrion birds
DefaultEvent.Description:
You ask the onlookers directly. "Conflagrati," says one, and titters. Another one curiously puts her hand on your forehead, as though to see whether you have a fever. 

It doesn't look as though any of them have gone sharp at all. What are they doing here?

ChildBranches.Name: Find out what all the onlookers are for
ChildBranches.Description: They aren't assisting in any medical proceedings.
